--- title: "Welcome to Stat 313!" title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: /images/background-bikeshare.png data-background-size: stretch data-background-opacity: "0.75" format: revealjs: theme: [night] editor: source execute: echo: false message: false warning: false --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {style="font-size: 4em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Warm-up ::: ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} (90 seconds) ::: . . . ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #b76352;"} Why do you believe your discipline requires / expects you to take this course? ::: # Who am I? ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} About Me... ::: ::: {.cell layout-nrow="1"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/running.jpg) ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/biking.JPG) ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/kitties.JPG) ::: ::: # What can I expect from this class? ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} What is Statistics? ::: . . . > Scientists seek to answer questions using rigorous methods and careful observations. These observations -- collected from the likes of field notes, surveys, and experiments -- form the backbone of a statistical investigation and are called data. ::: {style="color: #b76352;"} Statistics is the study of how best to collect, analyze, and draw conclusions from data. ::: > *Introduction to Modern Statistics* ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} What Statistics Is To Me :::

![The data science cycle -- Wickham & Grolemund](images/cycle.png) ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} What you can expect in STAT 313 ::: This course will teach you the fundamentals of linear models---*simple linear regression, multiple linear regression, and analysis of variance*---and experimental design. You will extend the concepts covered in your Stat I course, to: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} - work with data in a reproducible way (using R) - visualize and summarize a variety of datasets (in R) - critically evaluate the use of Statistics - perform statistical analyses to answer research questions (using R) ::: ## ::: {style="font-size: 4em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Coding ðŸ™€ ::: . . . Coding is a **huge** part of how doing statistics in the wild looks. . . . - Everyone is coming from a different background - Different aspects of the course will be difficult to different people - You will be given coding resources each week - Use your peers to support your learning ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Course Components ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="30%"} ::: {style="color: #b76352;"} *Before Class* ::: - Reading Guides - Concept Quizzes - R Tutorials ::: ::: {.column width="2%"} ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ::: {style="color: #76b5c5;"} *During Class* ::: - Group Discussion - Hands-on Activities - Lab Assignments ::: ::: {.column width="2%"} ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ::: {style="color: #e28743;"} *Outside of Class* ::: - Statistical Critiques - Midterm Project - Final Project ::: ::: ## {background-color="#B6CADA"} ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"} Specifications Based Grading ::: ![](images/four_pillars.png) . . . ::: {style="color: #000000;"} Everyone is capable of earning an A! ::: ## {background-color="#B6CADA"} ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #000000;"} How Smart are You? ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="30%"} (2 minutes) - Write two *criteria* would you use to *rank* yourself compared to everyone else in this class ::: ::: {.column width="2%"} ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} (3 minutes) - Talk with the person on your right about the criteria you proposed ::: ::: {.column width="2%"} ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} (5 minutes) - Share out - Person with most vowels in name should be prepared to share! ::: ::: ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Cooperative Learning ::: is a structured form of small-group learning . . .
::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} - Roles relate to **how** the work should be done - Roles **are not** about breaking up the work intellectually - Roles allow each person to contribute to the group in significant ways - Each person's participation is necessary to complete the task ::: ## {background-color="#B6CADA"} ::: {style="font-size: 3em; color: #000000;"} Group Norms ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="45%"} - Zero tolerance for: racism, sexism, homophobia, transphobia, ageism, ableism - Respect one another - Intent and impact *both* matter ::: ::: {.column width="5%"} ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} - Non-judgmental - Take space, make space - Embrace discomfort - Make decisions by consensus ::: ::: ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} How We Learn Together ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} - No one is done until everyone is done - You have the *right* to ask **anyone** in your group for help - You have the *duty* to help **anyone** in your group who asks for help ::: ::: ::: {.column width="5%"} ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} - Helping someone means explaining your thinking **not** giving answers or doing the work for them - Provide a justification when you make a statement - Think and work together -- don't divide up the work ::: ::: ::: ## {background-color="#B6CADA"} ::: {style="font-size: 8em; color: #000000;"} Break ::: # ::: {style="font-size: 4.5em;"} Let's talk about data... ::: ## ::: {style="font-size: 4em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Tidy Data ::: ![Expected layout of "tidy" datasets](images/tidy-1.png) ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Gender stereotypes in 5-7 year old children :::
::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
subject sex age trait target stereotype high_achieve_caution
133 male 6 smart adults 1.00 0.50
105 male 6 smart children 0.25 0.50
124 male 5 smart adults 0.50 0.75
136 male 6 smart children 1.00 0.00
139 male 7 nice children 0.75 0.75
14 male 7 smart adults 0.50 1.00
````` ::: ::: ::: ## ::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Body girth and skeletal diameter measurements ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
age wgt hgt sex sho_gi wai_gi nav_gi hip_gi
37 55.0 166.4 0 100.1 65.5 82.3 90.4
21 65.6 174.0 1 106.2 71.5 74.5 93.5
35 83.2 180.3 1 123.1 86.3 87.8 103.3
54 85.0 176.5 1 117.0 98.5 99.9 103.6
26 55.5 174.0 0 92.4 64.5 81.7 88.4
62 66.8 167.6 1 112.0 81.5 80.5 89.5
````` ::: ::: ::: ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} NBA player of the week :::
::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Age Date Draft Year Height Player Position
28 Mar 8, 2010 2003 6-4 Dwyane Wade SG
24 Mar 2, 2015 2012 6-3 Damian Lillard G
27 Mar 20, 2000 1994 6-8 Jalen Rose G
22 Mar 19, 1989 1987 6-1 Kevin Johnson PG
27 Apr 16, 2006 1996 6-6 Kobe Bryant SG
25 Nov 8, 2010 2004 6-11 Dwight Howard C
````` ::: ::: ::: ## {background-color="#B6CADA"} ::: {style="font-size: 3em; color: #000000;"} Your Turn ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} Every year, the US releases to the public a large data set containing information on births recorded in the country. A total of 13 variables were collected on every birth, including information about: - the birth (baby weight, sex of baby, premie status) - the pregnancy (hospital visits, length of gestation, ) - the birth parent's attributes (age, smoking status, marital status, race) - the partner's age ::: . . . ::: {style="color: #b76352;"} How would you expect this dataframe to look? ::: ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em;"} Military Spending ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Country 2010 2011 2012 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019
Africa NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
USA 4.922642 4.840174 4.477401 4.046679 3.695891 3.477846 3.418941 3.313385 3.316244 3.413107
Australia 1.856791 1.757078 1.670963 1.639861 1.772211 1.950601 2.081512 1.997974 1.894180 1.879802
Norway 1.515698 1.451436 1.402134 1.413997 1.472039 1.507280 1.626681 1.622270 1.628300 1.684120
Sweden 1.188288 1.104288 1.133304 1.116715 1.129776 1.069579 1.052833 1.024075 1.031100 1.120599
````` ::: ::: ::: . . .
::: {style="color: #b76352;"} Do these data satisfy the "tidy" principles? ::: ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em;"} Vehicle Efficiency ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb
Merc 280 19.2 6 167.6 123 3.92 3.440 18.30 1 0 4 4
Datsun 710 22.8 4 108.0 93 3.85 2.320 18.61 1 1 4 1
Mazda RX4 21.0 6 160.0 110 3.90 2.620 16.46 0 1 4 4
Fiat X1-9 27.3 4 79.0 66 4.08 1.935 18.90 1 1 4 1
````` ::: ::: ::: . . .
::: {style="color: #b76352;"} Do these data satisfy the "tidy" principles? ::: ## {background-color="#B6CADA"} ![Artwork by [\@allison_horst](https://twitter.com/allison_horst)](images/tidy-data.jpg) ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Types of Variables :::
![Diagram of types of variables we will analyze!](images/variables.png) ## {background-color="#B6CADA"}
![](images/continuous-discrete.jpeg)
## {background-color="#B6CADA"} ![](images/nominal_ordinal_binary.png) ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #76b5c5;"} Your Turn (90-seconds) :::
Write down one example of: - a **continuous, numerical** variable - a **discrete, numerical** variable - an **ordinal, categorical** variable - a **regular, categorical** variable . . . ::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #e28743;"} Share out! ::: # {background-color="#B6CADA"} ::: {style="font-size: 4em; color: #000000;"} Lab Warm-up ::: ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Data Types in `R` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="false"} glimpse(births_small) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 1,000 Columns: 10 $ fage 34, 36, 37, NA, 32, 32, 37, 29, 30, 29, 30, 34, 28, 28,â€¦ $ mage 34, 31, 36, 16, 31, 26, 36, 24, 32, 26, 34, 27, 22, 31,â€¦ $ weeks 37, 41, 37, 38, 36, 39, 36, 40, 39, 39, 42, 40, 40, 39,â€¦ $ premie "full term", "full term", "full term", "full term", "prâ€¦ $ gained 28, 41, 28, 29, 48, 45, 20, 65, 25, 22, 40, 30, 31, NA,â€¦ $ weight 6.96, 8.86, 7.51, 6.19, 6.75, 6.69, 6.13, 6.74, 8.94, 9â€¦ $ lowbirthweight "not low", "not low", "not low", "not low", "not low", â€¦ $ sex male, female, female, male, female, female, female, malâ€¦ $ habit "nonsmoker", "nonsmoker", "nonsmoker", "nonsmoker", "noâ€¦ $ whitemom "white", "white", "not white", "white", "white", "whiteâ€¦ ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="45%"} What do you think `dbl` means? How is that different from `int`? ::: ::: {.column width="5%"} ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} What does `chr` mean? How might it differ from `fct`? ::: ::: # Other Foundational Concepts ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Types of Studies ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} *Experiment* - randomization - replication - controlling - blocking ::: ::: {.column width="5%"} ::: ::: {.column width="55%"} *Observational Study* - collect data in a way that does not directly interfere with how the data arise ::: ::: ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Relationships Between Variables :::
explanatory variable $\rightarrow$ *might affect* $\rightarrow$ response variable . . . - If two variables are not associated, then they are said to be **independent**. - If two variables are associated, then they are said to be **dependent**. ## ::: {style="font-size: 2em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Causal Inference :::
association $\neq$ causation
. . . What do you need to say that the explanatory variable [*causes*]{style="color: #e28743;"} a change in the response variable? # Plan for Thursday ## Lab 1 - Access Posit Cloud from link posted on Canvas * Create an Account * Join the STAT 313 / 513 workspace * Access the Lab 1 Project * Open the Project
- A video will be posted guiding you on how to work with Quarto * Ask questions on Discord * Email / text / chat with your group members ## ::: {style="font-size: 4em; color: #FFFFFF;"} Find Your Group! :::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
